title: Su Song
caption: Chinese polymath who designed the 11m astronomical clock tower of Kaifeng (1090s) with hydraulic escapement and chain drive.

title: Jean Romilly
caption: Genevan watchmaker in Paris; contributor to the Encyclopédie; early calendar watch designs.

title: Pierre Jaquet-Droz
caption: Swiss maker of automata (Writer, Musician, Draughtsman) and musical watches; fused horology with early robotics.

title: Jean-Antoine Lépine
caption: Royal watchmaker; invented the Lépine calibre enabling thinner, simpler pocket watches.

title: Jean Rousseau
caption: Genevan horologist who helped establish Geneva as a European watchmaking center in the 17th century.

title: Abraham-Louis Breguet
caption: Seminal horologist: tourbillon (1801), self-winding 'perpétuelle', and iconic Breguet hands/numerals.

title: Christiaan Huygens
caption: Inventor of the pendulum clock (1656); foundational advances in precision timekeeping for science and observatories.

title: Galileo Galilei
caption: Pioneered pendulum timing concepts linking periodic motion with time measurement; inspired later practical pendulum clocks.

title: Robert Hooke
caption: Advanced balance-spring ideas and escapements; key to transforming watches into reliable portable timekeepers.

title: John Harrison
caption: Solved the ‘longitude problem’ with marine chronometers culminating in H4—revolutionizing navigation and global trade.

title: Thomas Tompion
caption: The ‘father of English watchmaking’; standardized production and mentored George Graham—raising English horology’s global stature.

title: George Graham
caption: Refined precision regulators and escapements; his observatory clocks underpinned Enlightenment-era measurements.

title: Ferdinand Berthoud
caption: Marine chronometer pioneer and prolific author; standardized methods and spread chronometry in France.

title: Pierre Le Roy
caption: Invented the detent escapement and temperature‑compensated balances; set the model for classical chronometers.

title: Antide Janvier
caption: Built planetariums, telluriums, and resonance clocks; poetic synthesis of mechanics and astronomy.

title: Louis Moinet
caption: Artist‑horologist and author of *Traité d’Horlogerie* (1848); linked precision timing with science and aesthetics.

title: Abraham‑Louis Perrelet
caption: Developed rotor‑style self‑winding mechanisms that prefigure modern automatics.

title: Richard of Wallingford
caption: Designed a sophisticated medieval astronomical clock for St Albans Abbey with lunar/tide indications.

title: Ismail al‑Jazari
caption: Authored *Book of Knowledge of Ingenious Mechanical Devices*; integrated hydraulics, gearing, and timing.

title: Jules Louis Audemars
caption: Co‑founded Audemars Piguet; specialized in complex movements that defined the maison’s identity.

title: Edward Auguste Piguet
caption: Co‑founded Audemars Piguet; anchored finishing standards and international growth.

title: Jean‑Moïse Japy
caption: Mechanized clock/watch parts in Franche‑Comté; standardized supply for European horology.

title: Monastic Bells & Daily Hours
caption: Monastic schedules structured communal time with bells—an early social clock for Europe.

title: Water Clocks & Automata of al‑Jazari
caption: Al‑Jazari’s programmable water clocks fused engineering, spectacle, and temporal order.

title: Town Clocks & Civic Time in Renaissance Europe
caption: Public turret clocks synchronized marketplaces, justice, and urban life.

title: The Pendulum Revolution
caption: Huygens’ pendulum transformed clocks from approximate to precise scientific instruments.

title: Solving Longitude at Sea
caption: Harrison’s chronometers enabled reliable longitude—remapping oceans and empires.

title: Factory Time & Industrial Discipline
caption: Industrial time standardized work rhythms, wages, and urban life.

title: Railroads & the Invention of Time Zones
caption: Rail and telegraph networks forced standardized time, culminating in global time zones.

title: Standard Time in North America
caption: ‘The Day of Two Noons’ brought coherent timekeeping to US–Canada rail and cities.

title: Quartz Time
caption: Quartz oscillators leapfrogged mechanical limits, seeding modern electronics.

title: Atomic Time, Satellites & GPS
caption: Cesium standards and GPS synchronized the planet—precision for navigation, telecom, and finance.
